module.p: ag is a special form of the adessive preposition aig, used before verbal nouns in the progressive construction.

section.p:
When the verbal noun starts with a vowel, the preposition takes the (deslenderised) form ag; otherwise, it takes the reduced form a’ –
Tha Raonaid a’ dèanamh rud Rachel is doing something
Tha Raonaid ag òl Rachel is drinking

Notes –
When the word preceding ag ends with a vowel, the particle often reduces to ’g in speech, and occasionally in writing too eg. tha mi ’g òl I’m drinking, thòisich i ’g ithe ùbhlan she started eating apples.
In older writing, the ag form is sometimes found before consonants as well, eg. ag bualadh (in the process of) hitting.
ag is used before ràdh (the verbal noun of abair say) ie. ag ràdh.

Basic pattern –
Tha Seumas ag èirigh James is rising
Tha Màiri a’ snàmh Mary is swimming

Examples from dictionaries and grammars –
Bha iad ag èigheach gu h-àrd. / Bha ag ràdh gun robh e sgìth.
They were shouting loudly. / He was saying that he was tired. td. 11

Older pedagogical examples –
Tha mo mhàthair a’ sgrìobhadh litreach gu m’athair a tha air falbh. Thubhairt mo mhàthair, “An téid thu do bhocsa nan litrichean leis an litir seo, Iain?” “Théid,” ars Iain, “falbhaidh mi an dràsda”. “Fuirich gus an dùin mi i is gus an cuir mi seòladh oirre. Ceannaich fhéin stamp agus cuir oirre i.” Tha Iain a’ ruith sìos an rathad leis an litir ’na làimh. Théid e a steach do oifig a’ phuist, ceannaichidh e stamp is cuiridh e sud air an litir. Tilgidh e an litir ann am bocsa nan litrichean.
My mother is writing a letter to my father who is away. My mother said, “Will you go to the postbox with this letter, John?” “Yes, I will,” said John, “I will leave now.” “Wait until I seal it and put an address on it. Buy a stamp and put it on it.” John is running down the road with the letter in his hand. He will go into the post office, he will buy a stamp and put that on the letter. He will toss the letter into the postbox. td. 5–6
Bha an latha brèagha blàth is thug an athair leis Iain agus Anna anns a’ chàr. Chaidh iad sìos taobh an locha is stad iad aig àite bòidheach gorm. Chuir iad an càr a stigh gu taobh an rathaid is thug iad brat a mach as a’ chàr air son suidhe air. Tha bascaid làn de bhiadh aca is tha iad a’ dol a ghabhail an tea air a’ chnocan ghorm. Is toigh leis a’ chloinn biadh a ghabhail a muigh ri latha brèagha. Thèid iad dhachaidh feasgar an uair a tha a’ ghrian a’ dol fodha.
The day was lovely and warm and their father took John and Ann in the car. They went down the side of the lake and they stopped at a beautiful green place. They put the car into the side of the road and they took a blanket out of the car for sitting on. They have a basket full of food and they are going to have their tea on the little green hill. The children like eating al fresco on a nice day. They will go home in the evening when the sun is going down. td. 6–7

Examples from Gairm –
Tha ar linn fhìn a’ coimhead gur e feallsanach mór a bh’ ann de Khierkegaard, gidheadh feallsanach eu-coltach ri a roi-shealbhadairean, ach a-mhàin, ’s math dh’ fhaoite, Nietzche.
Our own era views Kierkegaard as a great philosopher, even if a philosopher different to his predecessors, aside from, perhaps, Nietzsche. td. 103
Ma bha Hegel a’ déiligeadh ris an t-saoghal ar an taobh a-muigh, ’sann a bha Kierkegaard a’ déiligeadh gu tric ris an fheallsanach fhéin.
If Hegel dealt with the outside world, it was the philosopher himself that K. usually dealt with. td. 103

Other examples from modern usage –
[...] ’S ann an taigh Aonghais a’ Bhàillidh – caraid a bha còmhla ris san sgoil – a bhiodh Rob a’ fuireach nuair a bhiodh e aig an taigh. Bha muinntir Thòmais air an clachan fhàgail o chionn fhada. [...]
[...] It was in Angus of the Baillie’s house – a friend who was with him in the school – that Rob would be staying when he would be at home. Thomàs’ [Rob’s father] people had left the village long before. [...] td. 5 Habitual usage.

Basic pattern –
Tha Raonaid a’ pògadh nam balach Rachel is kissing the boys
Tha Iain ag ithe ubhail John is eating an apple

Pedagogical examples –
Bidh sinn a’ clàradh an òrain. / Chan eil iad a’ tuigsinn an t-suidheachaidh idir. / Chan eil mi ag iarraidh gum bi thu a’ rùsgadh nan ubhal air fad.
We’ll be recording the song. / They don’t understand the situation at all. / We don’t want you to be peeling all the apples. td. 122

Older pedagogical examples –
Tha mo mhàthair a’ sgrìobhadh litreach gu m’athair a tha air falbh.
My mother is writing a letter to my father who is away. td. 5

Examples from Gairm –
Bha feallsanach mar Hegel a’ togail riaghailtean móra a dheanadh an saoghal air a thaobh a-muigh fhéin soilleir, ach cha b’ ann mar sin a bha Kierkegaard.
A philosopher like Hegel constructed grand rules which made the external world itself clear but K. was not like that. td. 103

Other examples from modern usage –
[...] B’ e Rob a b’ òige agus lean e an sgoil. Nuair a ràinig e an t-oilthigh bha càch airson gun ionnsaicheadh e cunntasachd, a bhiodh feumail anns a’ mhalairt, ach ’s ann a bha ùidh-san ann an ealain. Dh’fhàg e an t-oilthigh agus chaidh e do sgoil ealain. Bha cuibhreann aige bho athair a bha tuilleadh ’s gu leòr airson fheumalachd ged a bha e dèidheil air a’ bhotal, agus cha robh e a’ dèanamh spàirn sam bith airson faighinn air adhart san t-saoghal. Bhiodh e a’ dèanamh sgrùdadh ealain do phàipear-naidheachd agus corra dhealbh, ach bha a chaitheamh-beatha glè fhada bho ùpraid muinntir Thòmais, no ‘mafia’ Thòmais, mar a chanadh e fhèin. Nuair a dh’innis e gu robh e air nighean a thoirt a dh’fhuireach còmhla ris, thuirt Tòmas ri càch, [...]
[...] Rob was the youngest [in the family] and he stayed on at school. When he reached the university the others wanted him to learn accountancy, which would be useful in the business, but his interest was in art. He left the university and went to an art school. He had an allowance from his father which more more than enough for his needs even though he was fond of the bottle, and he was not making any effort to get on in the world. He would be making art reviews for a newspaper and some pictures, but his way of life was very far from the commotion of Thomas’ people, or Thomas’ ‘mafia’, as he would say himself. When he announced that he had brought a girl to live with him, Thomas said to the others, [...] td. 5 Habitual usage.

Basic pattern –
Tha Raonaid gam mharbhadh Rachel is killing me
Tha Teàrlach gan atharrachadh Charles is changing them

Examples from dictionaries and grammars –
Tha iad gam bhrìodal. / Bidh sinn gur faicinn!
They are flattering/courting me. / We’ll be seeing you! td. 6
A bheil sibh gam fhaicinn? / Cha bhi sinn ga do thoirt leinn? / Bidh iad ga fhosgladh an-dràsta. / A bheil sibh ga h-iarraidh a-staigh sa bhad? / Bidh iad gar coinneachadh a-màireach. / Cha bhi sinn gur leigeil a-staigh gus a deich. / Dè mu na cait? Am bi thu gan cumail an seo?
Can you see me? / We won’t be taking you with us. / They’ll be opening it now. / Are you wanting her inside immediately? / They’ll be meeting us tomorrow. / We won’t be letting you in until ten. / What about the cats? Will you be keeping them here? td. 123

When the possessive determiner agrees with the subject in person, number and gender, a passive-like sense is possible –
Tha rud ga dhèanamh Something is being done
Tha rudan gan dèanamh Things are being done

Examples from dictionaries and grammars –
Bha a’ bhò ga bleoghann.
The cow was being milked. td. 6
Bha Gàidhlig ga bruidhinn air feadh Alba. / Tha leabhraichean gan reic anns a’ bhùth sin. / Bhiodh an t-òran sin ga ghabhail gu math tric air an rèidio.
Gaelic was (being) spoken all over Scotland. / Books are being sold in that shop. / That song used to be sung fairly often on the radio. td. 175
A bheil mi ga mo chlàradh an-dràsta? / Bha thu ga do tharraing a-steach gun fhiosta. / Bha sinn gar bualadh le clachan.
Am I being recorded now? / You were being drawn in unknowingly. / We were being struck by stones. td. 138

Examples with implicit bi –
“Cò tha an siud?” thuirt e, is e an doras ga fhosgladh. / Chuala mi uinneag ga fosgladh. / Leig iad sgreuch às, ’s iad gan sgaldàdh.
“Who’s there?” he said, as the door was being opened. / I heard a window being opened. / They let out a scream, as they were being scalded. td. 138

Other examples from modern usage –
Ann an Dùn Èideann anns na naochadan bha barrachd agus barrachd inbhich airson Gàidhlig ionnsachadh agus ged a nochd mòran chlasaichean agus cùrsaichean Gàidhlig airson iarrtasan nan daoine sin a fhreagradh, bha ionnsachadh na Gàidhlig ga bhacadh gu mòr air sgàth dìth shuidheachaidhean far an cluinnear an cànan ga bruidhinn gu nàdarra.
In Edinburgh in the 90s there were more and more people wanting to learn Gaelic and although a lot of Gaelic classes and courses sprang up to respond to the demands of those people, Gaelic learning was largely inhibited because of lack of situations where one could hear the language being spoken naturally. td. 85
